@CraigHRowland People largely then proceeded to run all the rules, never write their own, and complain about the noise. We invented a whole technology (RNA) at Sourcefire to help mitigate the problem.

@CraigHRowland Now I’ve decided that the best way to do it at scale across multi-cloud + on-prem networks is to raise the level of abstraction and look at the metadata and activities of the actors on the network. That’s what we’re up to at @netography.

RT @netography: Security for the Atomized Network requires a SaaS-based approach that can be deployed in minutes and immediately provide re…

There hasn't been an orderly transition from the enterprise networks of old to today's remote & mobile/ on-prem/multi-cloud enterprise. Networks have dispersed and become atomized.  Security architectures must evolve to match & Netography *is* security for the atomized network.

Computing isn't just "going to the cloud", it's evolving to be mobile and remote working with legacy on-prem, multi-cloud and hybrid cloud - you might call it atomized - and security architecture needs to evolve with it.

@dkarg @HackingDave That’s very true of tech in general and infosec in particular, especially when connected to startup culture. Eventually, neglecting your body drags the mind down with it. Can’t have one at peak capability while the other is left to languish.
@dkarg @HackingDave Also true that lots of infosec people really need to unplug from time to time and sailing would be good for the soul…

@dkarg @HackingDave Oh yeah that guy is hardcore, I follow him on IG.  I could certainly do a geek/infosec guy’s view of sailing. Lot to love if you’re coming from the tech/engineering side of the world into the sailing world.

@dkarg @HackingDave I’m in the land of plenty (Annapolis) where there are tons of qualified people available to work on the boats. I know tons about operating and racing them, lots less about the deep magic of rigging and nittt gritty maintenance.

@dkarg @HackingDave I have a small group of people I work with to keep my boats going because time and skills/experience are things that are in relatively short supply and money, relatively, is not. 😊
@dkarg @HackingDave Yeah you need to find a rigger for sure. Diesel mechanic and sail maker too.
@dkarg @HackingDave You can totally get them delivered, it just costs $$$.
@dkarg @HackingDave Like sail it 300 miles out on the ocean to the Columbia River??
@dkarg @HackingDave Do you trailer sail it?

@prophetskelter @dkarg @HackingDave Slant is called “heel” - your heel angle depends on a number of factors including the wind strength, how much sail you’ve got up, your angle to the wind, and how you have your sails trimmed. Generally above 20° of heel things get uncomfortable for everyone not ready for it.
@dkarg @HackingDave What do you feel like the big gaps are?  Most of my cruising is short handed and I did ny first double handed race a few weeks back.

@dkarg @HackingDave I don’t know, I bounce between cruising and racing so much I’m not sure what I’d even talk about that anyone would find interesting. “Today we’re going to listen to me curse under my breath while I debug this flakey GPS receiver on top of the rig.”

@ipninichuck @taosecurity @murribo @toddheberlein @snort @Suricata_IDS Tons of people got started like this, it’s a great path to understanding. Snort started small too, you can see the progression of the features and thinking, the dev of the rule language, if you look into the code base of the early 3-5 years. Original release was just a sniffer!

@murribo @taosecurity @toddheberlein @snort @snort is a component, I didn’t have a specific NSM/NTA agenda when I built it, just a feature set of things I thought were interesting/useful/essential. Obviously Snort has come a long way since then but I’d still say it’s a component of a larger suite of capabilities.
